ID   A85B_MYCKA              Reviewed;         325 AA.

DT   16-OCT-2013, entry version 58.
DE   RecName: Full=Diacylglycerol acyltransferase/mycolyltransferase Ag85B;
DE            Short=DGAT;
DE            EC=2.3.1.122;
DE            EC=2.3.1.20;
DE   AltName: Full=30 kDa extracellular protein;
DE   AltName: Full=Acyl-CoA:diacylglycerol acyltransferase;
DE   AltName: Full=Antigen 85 complex B;
DE            Short=85B;
DE            Short=Ag85B;
DE   AltName: Full=Extracellular alpha-antigen;
DE   AltName: Full=Fibronectin-binding protein B;
DE            Short=Fbps B;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=fbpB;
OS   Mycobacterium kansasii.
OC   Bacteria; Actinobacteria; Actinobacteridae; Actinomycetales;
OC   Corynebacterineae; Mycobacteriaceae; Mycobacterium.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=1768;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA].
RX   PubMed=2404875;
RA   Matsuo K., Yamaguchi R., Yamazaki A., Tasaka H., Terasaka K.,
RA   Yamada T.;
RT   "Cloning and expression of the gene for the cross-reactive alpha
RT   antigen of Mycobacterium kansasii.";
RL   Infect. Immun. 58:550-556(1990).
RN   [2]
RP   DOMAIN FIBRONECTIN BINDING.
RX   PubMed=9446601; DOI=10.1074/jbc.273.5.2905;
RA   Naito M., Ohara N., Matsumoto S., Yamada T.;
RT   "The novel fibronectin-binding motif and key residues of
RT   mycobacteria.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 273:2905-2909(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The antigen 85 proteins (FbpA, FbpB, FbpC) are
CC       responsible for the high affinity of mycobacteria for fibronectin,
CC       a large adhesive glycoprotein, which facilitates the attachment of
CC       M.tuberculosis to murine alveolar macrophages (AMs). They also
CC       help to maintain the integrity of the cell wall by catalyzing the
CC       transfer of mycolic acids to cell wall arabinogalactan and through
CC       the synthesis of alpha,alpha-trehalose dimycolate (TDM, cord
CC       factor). They catalyze the transfer of a mycoloyl residue from one
CC       molecule of alpha,alpha-trehalose monomycolate (TMM) to another
CC       TMM, leading to the formation of TDM (By similarity).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 alpha,alpha'-trehalose 6-mycolate =
CC       alpha,alpha'-trehalose + alpha,alpha'-trehalose 6,6'-bismycolate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Acyl-CoA + 1,2-diacylglycerol = CoA +
CC       triacylglycerol.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted (By similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the mycobacterial A85 antigen family.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Virulence factor required for host cell microfilament
CC       interaction. It induces actin assembly around the bacteria to
CC       allow it to move within the cytoplasm. It is involved in the actin
CC       polymerization process. It seems to act as a nucleator that
CC       induces the reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Single-pass membrane protein.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Aerolysin is a cytolytic toxin exported by the Gram
CC       negative Aeromonas bacteria. The mature toxin binds to eukaryotic
CC       cells and aggregates to form holes approximately 3 nm in diameter,
CC       leading to destruction of the membrane permeability barrier and
CC       osmotic lysis (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer in solution; heptamer in the membrane (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Host cell membrane.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the aerolysin family.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally thought to originate from A.sobria.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Absolutely required for the growth of E.coli in a high-
CC       phosphate medium containing G-1-P as the sole carbon source.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Alpha-D-glucose 1-phosphate + H(2)O = D-
CC       glucose + phosphate.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Independent from inorganic phosphate
CC       availability, and apparently submitted to catabolite repression,
CC       it is positively controlled by cAMP and the cAMP receptor protein.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is about 4;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the histidine acid phosphatase family.

RP   TOPOLOGY OF THE TRANSLOCATOR DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=10559167;
RA   Maurer J., Jose J., Meyer T.F.;
RT   "Characterization of the essential transport function of the AIDA-I
RT   autotransporter and evidence supporting structural predictions.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 181:7014-7020(1999).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   PubMed=15547278; DOI=10.1128/JB.186.23.8058-8065.2004;
RA   Sherlock O., Schembri M.A., Reisner A., Klemm P.;
RT   "Novel roles for the AIDA adhesin from diarrheagenic Escherichia coli:
RT   cell aggregation and biofilm formation.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 186:8058-8065(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potent bacterial adhesin that mediates bacterial
CC       attachment to a broad variety of human and other mammalian cells.
CC       AIDA possesses additional virulence properties, as it is capable
CC       of mediating bacterial autoaggregation via intercellular self-
CC       recognition and it is a highly efficient initiator of biofilm
CC       formation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Intercellular AIDA-AIDA interaction is responsible for
CC       bacterial autoaggregation. AIDA can also interact with antigen 43
CC       (Ag43), and the resultant intercellular AIDA-Ag43 interaction
CC       causes cell aggregation.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: AIDA-I autotransporter: Periplasm.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Adhesin AIDA-I: Secreted. Cell surface.
CC       Note=The N-terminal passenger domain containing the adhesin moity
CC       gains access to the surface.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: AIDA-I translocator: Cell outer membrane;
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein (Potential). Note=The cleaved AIDAc
CC       containing the translocator domain is localized in the outer
CC       membrane.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The signal peptide, cleaved at the inner membrane, guides
CC       the polyprotein to the periplasmic space. Then, insertion of the
CC       C-terminal translocator domain (or beta-domain) in the outer
CC       membrane forms a hydrophilic pore for the translocation of the
CC       passenger domain to the bacterial cell surface, with subsequent
CC       autocatalytic cleavage. Finally, the mature AIDA protein remains
CC       in contact with the cell surface via non-covalent interactions
CC       with the translocator pore.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated with an average of 19 heptose residues. Only the
CC       glycosylated form binds to mammalilan cells. But glycosylation of
CC       AIDA is not required for AIDA-mediated cell-cell aggregation,
CC       interaction with Ag43, and induction of biofilm formation.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 autotransporter (TC 1.B.12) domain.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Primary acceptor of electrons from methylamine

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Since only maltooligosaccharides up to a chain length of
CC       6 glucose units are actively transported through the cytoplasmic
CC       membrane via the membrane-bound complex of three proteins, MalF,
CC       MalG, and MalK, longer maltooligosaccharides must first be
CC       degraded by the periplasmic alpha-amylase, the MalS protein.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic
CC       linkages in polysaccharides containing three or more (1->4)-alpha-
CC       linked D-glucose units.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 calcium ion per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Under the regulatory control of the MalT protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The precursor protein is proteolytically cleaved to
CC       produce multiform beta-amylases and a 48 kDa alpha-amylase after
CC       secretion.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Hydrolysis of (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic
CC       linkages in polysaccharides so as to remove successive maltose
CC       units from the non-reducing ends of the chains.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic
CC       linkages in polysaccharides containing three or more (1->4)-alpha-
CC       linked D-glucose units.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the glycosyl
CC       hydrolase 14 family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the glycosyl
CC       hydrolase 13 family.

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic
CC       linkages in polysaccharides containing three or more (1->4)-alpha-
CC       linked D-glucose units.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 3 calcium ions per subunit.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 sodium ion per subunit.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Active up to pH 11;
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Active up to 100 degrees Celsius;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- BIOTECHNOLOGY: Used in the food industry for high temperature
CC       liquefaction of starch-containing mashes and in the detergent
CC       industry to remove starch. Sold under the name Termamyl by
CC       Novozymes.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.

RX   PubMed=18216068; DOI=10.1093/jb/mvn007;
RA   Sakaguchi M., Takezawa M., Nakazawa R., Nozawa K., Kusakawa T.,
RA   Nagasawa T., Sugahara Y., Kawakita M.;
RT   "Role of disulphide bonds in a thermophilic serine protease aqualysin
RT   I from Thermus aquaticus YT-1.";
RL   J. Biochem. 143:625-632(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Aqualysin I is a thermophilic alkaline serine protease.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Exhibits low specificity toward esters of
CC       amino acids with small hydrophobic or aromatic residues at the P1
CC       position.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 80 degrees Celsius for caseinolytic
CC         activity;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Secreted from the early stationary phase
CC       until the time the cells cease to grow.
CC   -!- PTM: The N- and C-terminal Pro-sequences are successively removed
CC       through the proteolytic activity of PstI itself. The C-terminal
CC       Pro-sequence is required for translocation of the proteases across
CC       the outer membrane.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S8 family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the high-affinity L-arabinose membrane
CC       transport system. Binds with high affinity to arabinose, but can
CC       also bind D-galactose (approximately 2-fold reduction) and D-
CC       fucose (approximately 40-fold reduction).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial solute-binding protein 2
CC       family.

RL   Acta Crystallogr. D 59:416-422(2003).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: L-asparagine + H(2)O = L-aspartate + NH(3).
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.115 uM for L-asparagine;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By cAMP and anaerobiosis.
CC   -!- PHARMACEUTICAL: Available under the names Crastinin (Bayer),
CC       Elspar (Merck), Kidrolase (Rhone-Poulenc) and Leunase (Kyowa).
CC       Also available as a PEG-conjugated form (Pegaspargase) under the
CC       name Oncaspar (Enzon). Used as an antineoplastic in chemotherapy.
CC       Reduces the quantity of asparagine available to cancer cells.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: E.coli contains two L-asparaginase isoenzymes: L-
CC       asparaginase I, a low-affinity enzyme located in the cytoplasm,
CC       and L-asparaginase II, a high-affinity secreted enzyme.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the asparaginase 1 family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Worthington enzyme manual;
CC       URL="http://www.worthington-biochem.com/ASPR/";

RN   [15]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.28 ANGSTROMS) OF TEM-1.
RX   PubMed=10423234; DOI=10.1021/bi990758z;
RA   Swaren P., Golemi D., Cabantous S., Bulychev A., Maveyraud L.,
RA   Mobashery S., Samama J.-P.;
RT   "X-ray structure of the Asn276Asp variant of the Escherichia coli TEM-
RT   1 beta-lactamase: direct observation of electrostatic modulation in
RT   resistance to inactivation by clavulanic acid.";
RL   Biochemistry 38:9570-9576(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: TEM-type are the most prevalent beta-lactamases in
CC       enterobacteria; they hydrolyze the beta-lactam bond in susceptible
CC       beta-lactam antibiotics, thus conferring resistance to penicillins
CC       and cephalosporins. TEM-3 and TEM-4 are capable of hydrolyzing
CC       cefotaxime and ceftazidime. TEM-5 is capable of hydrolyzing
CC       ceftazidime. TEM-6 is capable of hydrolyzing ceftazidime and
CC       aztreonam. TEM-8/CAZ-2, TEM-16/CAZ-7 and TEM-24/CAZ-6 are markedly
CC       active against ceftazidime. IRT-4 shows resistance to beta-
CC       lactamase inhibitors.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A beta-lactam + H(2)O = a substituted beta-
CC       amino acid.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P35804:- (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1031989, EBI-1031985;
CC   -!- BIOTECHNOLOGY: This protein is used as a marker in many commonly
CC       used cloning vectors, such as pBR322 and the pUC series.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The beta-lactamase present on pBR322 was cloned
CC       from plasmid R1 (R7268).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class-A beta-lactamase family.

RL   Nat. Struct. Biol. 10:948-954(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the active translocation of vitamin B12
CC       (cyanocobalamin) across the outer membrane to the periplasmic
CC       space. It derives its energy for transport by interacting with the
CC       trans-periplasmic membrane protein TonB. Is also a receptor for
CC       bacteriophages BF23 and C1, and for A and E colicins.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Calcium increases vitamin B12 binding affinity
CC       by a factor of 50-100.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with TonB.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P00646:ceaC (xeno); NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-1037258, EBI-1029919;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Constitutively expressed. Primary control of btuB
CC       expression by cobalamin occurs at the level of translation
CC       initiation.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TonB-dependent receptor family. BtuB
CC       (TC 1.B.14.3.1) subfamily.

RP   VITAMIN B12.
RX   PubMed=12468528; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M212239200;
RA   Karpowich N.K., Huang H.H., Smith P.C., Hunt J.F.;
RT   "Crystal structures of the BtuF periplasmic-binding protein for
RT   vitamin B12 suggest a functionally important reduction in protein
RT   mobility upon ligand binding.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 278:8429-8434(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the ABC transporter complex BtuCDF involved in
CC       vitamin B12 import. Binds vitamin B12 and delivers it to the
CC       periplasmic surface of BtuC.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (BtuD), two transmembrane proteins (BtuC) and a solute-binding
CC       protein (BtuF).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Vitamin B12 is bound in a deep cleft formed at the
CC       interface between the two lobes of BtuF.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the BtuF family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 Fe/B12 periplasmic-binding domain.

DE            EC=3.4.21.110;
DE   AltName: Full=SCP;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=scpA;
OS   Streptococcus pyogenes.

OC   Streptococcus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=1314;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA], AND PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 32-41.
RX   PubMed=2406246;
RA   Chen C.C., Cleary P.P.;
RT   "Complete nucleotide sequence of the streptococcal C5a peptidase gene
RT   of Streptococcus pyogenes.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 265:3161-3167(1990).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This virulence factor of S.pyogenes specifically cleaves
CC       the human serum chemotaxin C5a at '68-Lys-|-Asp-69' bond near its
CC       C-terminus, destroying its ability to serve as a chemoattractant.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: The primary cleavage site is at 67-His-|-Lys-
CC       68 in human C5a with a minor secondary cleavage site at 58-Ala-|-
CC       Ser-59.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, cell wall; Peptidoglycan-anchor
CC       (Potential).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S8 family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the hydrolysis of reduced and non-reduced
CC       folates to pteroates and L-glutamate. This enzyme has a broad
CC       specificity.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Release of C-terminal glutamate residues from
CC       a wide range of N-acylating moieties, including peptidyl,
CC       aminoacyl, benzoyl, benzyloxycarbonyl, folyl and pteroyl groups.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 zinc ions per subunit.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer.
CC   -!- PHARMACEUTICAL: Used clinically as a folate-depleting, antitumor
CC       agent.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase M20A family.

RA   Wery J.-P., Charlier P., Dideberg O.;
RL   Submitted (MAR-1996) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This enzyme catalyzes carboxypeptidation and
CC       transpeptidation reactions involved in bacterial cell wall
CC       metabolism. It effectively catalyzes the transfer of the N-alpha,
CC       N-epsilon-diacetyl-L-lysyl-D-alanyl electrophilic group of the
CC       standard tripeptide substrate N-alpha,N-epsilon-diacetyl-L-lysyl-
CC       D-alanyl-D-alanine to water. It also performs a weak beta-
CC       lactamase activity, hydrolyzing penicillin into penicilloate at a
CC       very low rate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cleavage of the bond: (Ac)(2)-L-lysyl-D-
CC       alanyl-|-D-alanine.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is partially blocked as a result of the
CC       cyclization of the first two amino acids into
CC       anhydroaspartylglycine imide.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase M15 family.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA] OF 23-346.
RX   PubMed=8543038; DOI=10.1016/0014-5793(95)01326-1;
RA   Samyn B., van Craenenbroeck K., de Smet L., Vandenberghe I.,
RA   Pettigrew G., van Beeumen J.;

RT   cytochrome c peroxidase.";

RN   [4]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 24-346.
RX   PubMed=2546794; DOI=10.1016/0014-5793(89)80714-8;
RA   Roennberg M., Kalkkinen N., Ellfolk N.;
RT   "The primary structure of Pseudomonas cytochrome c peroxidase.";
RL   FEBS Lett. 250:175-178(1989).
RN   [5]
RP   PARTIAL PROTEIN SEQUENCE.
RX   PubMed=3030432;
RA   Roennberg M.;
RT   "Amino acid sequences of the two heme c-binding sites of Pseudomonas
RT   cytochrome-c peroxidase.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 912:82-86(1987).
RN   [6]
RP   CHARACTERIZATION.
RX   PubMed=1657179; DOI=10.1016/0167-4838(91)90113-E;
RA   Ellfolk N., Roennberg M., Oesterlund K.;
RT   "Structural and functional features of Pseudomonas cytochrome c
RT   peroxidase.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1080:68-77(1991).
RN   [7]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.4 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=8591033; DOI=10.1016/S0969-2126(01)00258-1;
RA   Fueloep V., Ridout C.J., Greenwood C., Hajdu J.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the di-haem cytochrome c peroxidase from
RT   Pseudomonas aeruginosa.";
RL   Structure 3:1225-1233(1995).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the peroxidative oxidation of azurin and
CC       cytochrome c551. Likely to provide protection against toxic
CC       peroxides.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 ferrocytochrome c + H(2)O(2) = 2
CC       ferricytochrome c + 2 H(2)O.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 heme groups. Heme 1 is low-potential (-330 mV)
CC       with 2 His axial ligands and functions in the peroxidase reaction,
CC       while heme 2 is high potential (+320 mV) with His and Met axial
CC       ligands and functions to feed electrons from electron-shuttle
CC       proteins such as cytochrome c and azurin.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Organized into two domains, each containing a covalent c-
CC       heme in a structure reminiscent of class 1 cytochromes c. The
CC       domains are related by a quasi-twofold axis. The domain interface
CC       contains a calcium-binding site with an unusual set of ligands.
CC   -!- PTM: Binds 2 heme groups per subunit.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cyclizes part of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan chain
CC       by formation of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic bond.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted (By similarity).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: May consist of two protein domains: the one in the N-
CC       terminal side cleaves the alpha-1,4-glucosidic bond in starch, and
CC       the other in the C-terminal side catalyzes other activities,
CC       including the reconstitution of an alpha-1,4-glucosidic linkage
CC       for cyclizing the maltooligosaccharide produced.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CBM20 (carbohydrate binding type-20)
CC       domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 IPT/TIG domain.

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cyclizes part of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan chain
CC       by formation of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic bond.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted (By similarity).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: May consist of two protein domains: the one in the N-
CC       terminal side cleaves the alpha-1,4-glucosidic bond in starch, and
CC       the other in the C-terminal side catalyzes other activities,
CC       including the reconstitution of an alpha-1,4-glucosidic linkage
CC       for cyclizing the maltooligosaccharide produced.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CBM20 (carbohydrate binding type-20)
CC       domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 IPT/TIG domain.

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cyclizes part of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan chain
CC       by formation of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic bond.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted (By similarity).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: May consist of two protein domains: the one in the N-
CC       terminal side cleaves the alpha-1,4-glucosidic bond in starch, and
CC       the other in the C-terminal side catalyzes other activities,
CC       including the reconstitution of an alpha-1,4-glucosidic linkage
CC       for cyclizing the maltooligosaccharide produced.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CBM20 (carbohydrate binding type-20)
CC       domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 IPT/TIG domain.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA] OF 1-586.

RT   "Nucleotide sequence of the cyclomaltodextrin glucanotransferase
RT   (CGTase) gene from alkalophilic Bacillus sp. strain No. 38-2.";
RL   Agric. Biol. Chem. 51:2019-2022(1987).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cyclizes part of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan chain
CC       by formation of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic bond.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted (By similarity).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: May consist of two protein domains: the one in the N-
CC       terminal side cleaves the alpha-1,4-glucosidic bond in starch, and
CC       the other in the C-terminal side catalyzes other activities,
CC       including the reconstitution of an alpha-1,4-glucosidic linkage
CC       for cyclizing the maltooligosaccharide produced.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CBM20 (carbohydrate binding type-20)
CC       domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 IPT/TIG domain.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Degrades starch to alpha-, beta-, and gamma-
CC       cyclodextrins, as well as linear sugars.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cyclizes part of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan chain
CC       by formation of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic bond.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.

CC       domain.

CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally (PubMed:1854207) thought to be an alpha-
CC       amylase.

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cyclizes part of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan chain
CC       by formation of a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucosidic bond.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: May consist of two protein domains: the one in the N-
CC       terminal side cleaves the alpha-1,4-glucosidic bond in starch, and
CC       the other in the C-terminal side catalyzes other activities,
CC       including the reconstitution of an alpha-1,4-glucosidic linkage
CC       for cyclizing the maltooligosaccharide produced.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 13 family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CBM20 (carbohydrate binding type-20)
CC       domain.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Bifunctional enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of the
CC       3-beta-hydroxy group of cholesterol and the isomerization of the
CC       double bond of the resulting product.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cholesterol + O(2) = cholest-5-en-3-one +
CC       H(2)O(2).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A 3-oxo-Delta(5)-steroid = a 3-oxo-Delta(4)-
CC       steroid.

CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- PTM: Predicted to be exported by the Tat system. The position of
CC       the signal peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GMC oxidoreductase family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidation and isomerization of cholesterol
CC       to cholestenone (4-cholesten-3-one), which is an initial step in
CC       the cholesterol degradation process.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cholesterol + O(2) = cholest-5-en-3-one +
CC       H(2)O(2).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A 3-oxo-Delta(5)-steroid = a 3-oxo-Delta(4)-
CC       steroid.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: FAD.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Steroid metabolism; cholesterol metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- PTM: Predicted to be exported by the Tat system. The position of
CC       the signal peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GMC oxidoreductase family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The B subunit pentameric ring directs the A subunit to
CC       its target by binding to the GM1 gangliosides present on the
CC       surface of the intestinal epithelial cells. It can bind five GM1
CC       gangliosides. It has no toxic activity by itself.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The holotoxin (choleragen) consists of a pentameric ring
CC       of B subunits whose central pore is occupied by the A subunit. The
CC       A subunit contains two chains, A1 and A2, linked by a disulfide
CC       bridge.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P01555:ctxA; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1038383, EBI-1038392;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Host cell membrane (Potential).

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 19-38 AND 213-232.
RX   PubMed=955672; DOI=10.1016/0019-2791(76)90173-7;
RA   Klapper D.G., Finkelstein R.A., Capra J.D.;
RT   "Subunit structure and N-terminal amino acid sequence of the three
RT   chains of cholera enterotoxin.";
RL   Immunochemistry 13:605-611(1976).
RN   [11]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 27-72 AND 111-139.
RX   PubMed=437113; DOI=10.1016/0014-5793(79)81136-9;
RA   Lai C.-Y., Cancedda F., Chang D.;

RL   FEBS Lett. 100:85-89(1979).
RN   [12]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 213-258.
RX   PubMed=7028752;
RA   Duffy L.K., Peterson J.W., Kurosky A.;
RT   "Covalent structure of the gamma chain of the A subunit of cholera
RT   toxin.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 256:12252-12256(1981).
RN   [13]
RP   INTERACTION BETWEEN CHOLERA TOXIN AND ADENYLATE CYCLASE.
RX   PubMed=4323551; DOI=10.1038/229266a0;
RA   Sharp G.W., Hynie S.;
RT   "Stimulation of intestinal adenyl cyclase by cholera toxin.";
RL   Nature 229:266-269(1971).

RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=3214; DOI=10.1021/bi00651a011;
RA   Gill D.M.;
RT   "The arrangement of subunits in cholera toxin.";
RL   Biochemistry 15:1242-1248(1976).
RN   [15]
RP   TRANSPORT OF CHOLERA TOXIN WITHIN THE INTESTINAL CELL.
RX   PubMed=13679513; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E03-06-0354;
RA   Fujinaga Y., Wolf A.A., Rodighiero C., Wheeler H., Tsai B., Allen L.,
RA   Jobling M.G., Rapoport T., Holmes R.K., Lencer W.I.;
RT   "Gangliosides that associate with lipid rafts mediate transport of
RT   cholera and related toxins from the plasma membrane to endoplasmic
RT   reticulm.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 14:4783-4793(2003).
RN   [16]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.4 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=7658473; DOI=10.1006/jmbi.1995.0456;
RA   Zhang R.-G., Scott D.L., Westbrook M.L., Nance S., Spangler B.D.,
RA   Shipley G.G., Westbrook E.M.;
RT   "The three-dimensional crystal structure of cholera toxin.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 251:563-573(1995).
RN   [17]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.8 ANGSTROMS) OF 19-210 IN COMPLEX WITH NAD
RP   AND HUMAN ARF6, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=16099990; DOI=10.1126/science.1113398;
RA   O'Neal C.J., Jobling M.G., Holmes R.K., Hol W.G.;
RT   "Structural basis for the activation of cholera toxin by human ARF6-
RT   GTP.";
RL   Science 309:1093-1096(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The A1 chain catalyzes the ADP-ribosylation of Gs alpha,
CC       a GTP-binding regulatory protein, to activate the adenylate
CC       cyclase. This leads to an overproduction of cAMP and eventually to
CC       a hypersecretion of chloride and bicarbonate followed by water,
CC       resulting in the characteristic cholera stool. The A2 chain
CC       tethers A1 to the pentameric ring.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The holotoxin (choleragen) consists of a pentameric ring
CC       of B subunits whose central pore is occupied by the A subunit. The
CC       A subunit contains two chains, A1 and A2, linked by a disulfide
CC       bridge. Interaction with the host protein ARF6 causes a
CC       conformation change so that the enterotoxin subunit A1 can bind
CC       NAD and catalyze the ADP-ribosylation of the host Gs alpha.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P01556:ctxB; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1038392, EBI-1038383;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The four C-terminal residues of the A2 chain occupy the
CC       central pore of the holotoxin. Deletion of these residues weakens
CC       the interaction between the A subunit and the B pentamer without
CC       impairing the pentamer formation.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: After binding to gangliosides GM1 in lipid rafts,
CC       through the subunit B pentamer, the holotoxin and the gangliosides
CC       are internalized. The holotoxin remains bound to GM1 until arrival
CC       in the ER. The A subunit has previously been cleaved in the
CC       intestinal lumen but the A1 and A2 chains have remained
CC       associated. In the ER, the A subunit disulfide bridge is reduced,
CC       the A1 chain is unfolded by the PDI and disassembled from the rest
CC       of the toxin. Then, the membrane-associated ER oxidase ERO1
CC       oxidizes PDI, which releases the unfolded A1 chain. The next step
CC       is the retrotranslocation of A1 into the cytosol. This might be
CC       mediated by the protein-conducting pore SEC61. Upon arrival in the
CC       cytosol, A1 refolds and avoids proteasome degradation. In one way
CC       or another, A1 finally reaches its target and induces toxicity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the enterotoxin A family.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RT   "The crystal structure of a type I cohesin domain at 1.7-A
RT   resolution.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 273:701-713(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as a scaffolding protein in the cellulosome. It
CC       promotes binding of cellulose to the catalytic domains of the
CC       cellulolytic enzymes.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Note=Remains at the cell surface.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The cohesin domains bind to the dockerin domain born by
CC       the catalytic components of the cellulosome.
CC   -!- PTM: O-glycosylated on most but not all Thr residues of the linker
CC       units. The reducing sugar is galactopyranose.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CBM3 (carbohydrate binding type-3) domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 9 cohesin domains.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 dockerin domains.

RC   STRAIN=K12 / EMG2;
RX   PubMed=9298646; DOI=10.1002/elps.1150180807;

RT   in the genome of Escherichia coli K-12.";
RL   Electrophoresis 18:1259-1313(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This bifunctional enzyme catalyzes two consecutive
CC       reactions during ribonucleic acid degradation. Converts a 2',3'-
CC       cyclic nucleotide to a 3'-nucleotide and then the 3'-nucleotide to
CC       the corresponding nucleoside and phosphate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Nucleoside 2',3'-cyclic phosphate + H(2)O =
CC       nucleoside 3'-phosphate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A 3'-ribonucleotide + H(2)O = a ribonucleoside
CC       + phosphate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Divalent cations (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Two kinetically distinguishable active sites for
CC       the two substrates (2',3'-cyclic nucleotides and 3'-nucleotides)
CC       have been identified.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 5'-nucleotidase family.

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 228-270.
RC   STRAIN=HG66;
RX   PubMed=1527017;
RA   Chen Z., Potempa J., Polanowski A., Wikstrom M., Travis J.;
RT   "Purification and characterization of a 50-kDa cysteine proteinase
RT   (gingipain) from Porphyromonas gingivalis.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 267:18896-18901(1992).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Thiol protease which is believed to participate in
CC       intracellular degradation and turnover of proteins. Its
CC       proteolytic activity is a major factor in both periodontal tissue
CC       destruction and in bacterial host defense mechanisms. Activates
CC       complement C3 and C5.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Hydrolysis of proteins and small molecule
CC       substrates, with a preference for Arg in P1.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Requires cysteine for activation and Ca(2+)
CC       and/or Mg(2+) for stabilization. It is stimulated by glycine-
CC       containing dipeptides. It is resistant to inhibition by proteinase
CC       inhibitors in human plasma.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C25 family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Curlin is the structural subunit of the curli fimbriae.
CC       Curli are coiled surface structures that assemble preferentially
CC       at growth temperatures below 37 degrees Celsius. Curli can bind to
CC       fibronectin.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Fimbrium. Note=Part of the curli surface
CC       structure.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Under control of the CsgD transcription factor, part of
CC       the csgBAC/ymdA operon.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CsgA/CsgB family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The S-layer is a paracrystalline mono-layered assembly
CC       of proteins which coat the surface of the cell.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, cell wall, S-layer. Cell membrane.
CC       Note=This archaeon is covered by an S-layer with hexagonal
CC       symmetry. S-layer glycoproteins are anchored to the plasma
CC       membrane as well as being surface-exposed.
CC   -!- PTM: N-linked glycan at Asn-36 consists of a glycosaminoglycan
CC       chain, constructed by a repeating sulfated pentasaccharide block
CC       composed of GlcNAc, GalNAc, Gal, GalA, 3-O-methyl-GalA, and
CC       sulfate in the molar ratio of 1:1:1:1:1:2; the other N-linked
CC       glycans contain Glc, GlcA and IdoA.
CC   -!- PTM: O-linked glycans consist of Glc-Gal disaccharides.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the halobacterial S-layer protein family.

CC       Sequence=AAG20702.1; Type=Erroneous initiation;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The S-layer is a paracrystalline mono-layered assembly
CC       of proteins which coat the surface of the cell.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, cell wall, S-layer. Cell membrane.
CC       Note=This archaeon is covered by an S-layer with hexagonal
CC       symmetry. S-layer glycoproteins are anchored to the plasma
CC       membrane as well as being surface-exposed.
CC   -!- PTM: O-glycosylated on 4 to 6 threonine residues; glycans consist
CC       of Glc-Gal disaccharides.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is not blocked.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated; glycans contain mannose, galactose, glucose
CC       and idose with a relative ratio of 1/3/3/0.2.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the halobacterial S-layer protein family.

RT   encoded by the Escherichia coli yacK gene.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 183:4866-4875(2001).
RN   [10]
RP   CHARACTERIZATION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF 500-CYS-HIS-501.
RC   STRAIN=K12 / W3110 / ATCC 27325 / DSM 5911;
RX   PubMed=11527384; DOI=10.1006/bbrc.2001.5474;
RA   Grass G., Rensing C.;
RT   "CueO is a multi-copper oxidase that confers copper tolerance in
RT   Escherichia coli.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 286:902-908(2001).
RN   [11]
RP   EXPORT VIA THE TAT-SYSTEM AND THE SEC-SYSTEM.
RX   PubMed=17218314; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M610507200;
RA   Tullman-Ercek D., DeLisa M.P., Kawarasaki Y., Iranpour P.,
RA   Ribnicky B., Palmer T., Georgiou G.;
RT   "Export pathway selectivity of Escherichia coli twin arginine
RT   translocation signal peptides.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 282:8309-8316(2007).
RN   [12]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.4 ANGSTROMS).
RC   STRAIN=K12 / W3110 / ATCC 27325 / DSM 5911;
RX   PubMed=11867755; DOI=10.1073/pnas.052710499;
RA   Roberts S.A., Weichsel A., Grass G., Thakali K., Hazzard J.T.,
RA   Tollin G., Rensing C., Montfort W.R.;
RT   "Crystal structure and electron transfer kinetics of CueO, a
RT   multicopper oxidase required for copper homeostasis in Escherichia
RT   coli.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99:2766-2771(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probably involved in periplasmic detoxification of
CC       copper by oxidizing Cu(+) to Cu(2+) and thus preventing its uptake
CC       into the cytoplasm. Possesses phenoloxidase and ferroxidase
CC       activities and might be involved in the production of polyphenolic
CC       compounds and the prevention of oxidative damage in the periplasm.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 4 copper ions per monomer.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm. Note=It is exported via the Tat
CC       pathway.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By CueR, at increased levels of cytoplasmic cuprous
CC       ions.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The methionine-rich domain could provide binding sites for
CC       exogenous copper ions. This methionine-rich region is probably
CC       important for copper tolerance in bacteria.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven. Can also be
CC       exported by the Sec system.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This protein is sensitive to oxygen deprivation. It
CC       probably plays a significant role in copper efflux under aerobic
CC       conditions.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the multicopper oxidase family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 3 plastocyanin-like domains.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Autolysins are involved in some important biological
CC       processes such as cell separation, cell-wall turnover, competence
CC       for genetic transformation, formation of the flagella and
CC       sporulation.

CC       residues and L-amino acid residues in certain cell-wall
CC       glycopeptides.

CC       N-terminal fragment (AA 1-196).

CC       family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytochrome c2 is found mainly in purple, non-sulfur,
CC       photosynthetic bacteria where it functions as the electron donor
CC       to the oxidized bacteriochlorophyll in the photophosphorylation
CC       pathway. However, it may also have a role in the respiratory chain
CC       and is found in some non-photosynthetic bacteria.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA].
RX   PubMed=2842748; DOI=10.1073/pnas.85.16.5794;
RA   Kallas T., Spiller S., Malkin R.;
RT   "Primary structure of cotranscribed genes encoding the Rieske Fe-S and
RT   cytochrome f proteins of the cyanobacterium Nostoc PCC 7906.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 85:5794-5798(1988).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the cytochrome b6-f complex, which mediates
CC       electron transfer between photosystem II (PSII) and photosystem I
CC       (PSI), cyclic electron flow around PSI, and state transitions (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 heme group covalently (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The 4 large subunits of the cytochrome b6-f complex are
CC       cytochrome b6, subunit IV (17 kDa polypeptide, PetD), cytochrome f
CC       and the Rieske protein, while the 4 small subunits are PetG, PetL,
CC       PetM and PetN. The complex functions as a dimer (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cellular thylakoid membrane; Single-pass
CC       membrane protein (By similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome f family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the ABC transporter complex CysAWTP
CC       (TC 3.A.1.6.1) involved in sulfate/thiosulfate import. This
CC       protein specifically binds thiosulfate and is involved in its
CC       transmembrane transport.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (CysA), two transmembrane proteins (CysT and CysW) and a solute-
CC       binding protein (CysP) (Probable).
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P0A6Y8:dnaK; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-560567, EBI-542092;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the prokaryotic sulfate-binding protein
CC       family.

RA   Yoshikawa H., Danchin A.;
RT   "The complete genome sequence of the Gram-positive bacterium Bacillus
RT   subtilis.";
RL   Nature 390:249-256(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Removes C-terminal D-alanyl residues from sugar-peptide
CC       cell wall precursors. Required specifically for the synthesis of
CC       the spore form of peptidoglycan (cortex).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Preferential cleavage: (Ac)(2)-L-Lys-D-Ala-|-
CC       D-Ala. Also transpeptidation of peptidyl-alanyl moieties that are
CC       N-acyl substituents of D-alanine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Cell wall biogenesis; peptidoglycan biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Forespore outer membrane; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed at about stage III of sporulation.
CC       Likely to be expressed specifically in the mother cell.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S11 family.

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=2046551; DOI=10.1111/j.1365-2958.1991.tb00739.x;
RA   Korat B., Mottl H., Keck W.;
RT   "Penicillin-binding protein 4 of Escherichia coli: molecular cloning
RT   of the dacB gene, controlled overexpression, and alterations in murein
RT   composition.";
RL   Mol. Microbiol. 5:675-684(1991).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Not involved in transpeptidation but exclusively
CC       catalyzes a DD-carboxypeptidase and DD-endopeptidase reaction.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Preferential cleavage: (Ac)(2)-L-Lys-D-Ala-|-
CC       D-Ala. Also transpeptidation of peptidyl-alanyl moieties that are
CC       N-acyl substituents of D-alanine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Cell wall biogenesis; peptidoglycan biosynthesis.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P0A6E4:argG; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-1131834, EBI-1120296;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm (Potential).
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In E.coli there are three murein endopeptidases:
CC       two are penicillin sensitive (DacB and PbpG), the other (MepA)
CC       not.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S13 family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Removes C-terminal D-alanyl residues from sugar-peptide

RA   Silvaggi N.R., Josephine H.R., Kuzin A.P., Nagarajan R., Pratt R.F.,
RA   Kelly J.A.;
RT   "Crystal structures of complexes between the R61 DD-peptidase and
RT   peptidoglycan-mimetic beta-lactams: a non-covalent complex with a
RT   'perfect penicillin'.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 345:521-533(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes distinct carboxypeptidation and
CC       transpeptidation reactions during the last stages of wall
CC       peptidoglycan synthesis. Mistaking a beta-lactam antibiotic
CC       molecule for a normal substrate (i.e. a D-alanyl-D-alanine-
CC       terminated peptide), it becomes immobilized in the form of a long-
CC       lived, serine-ester-linked acyl enzyme and thus behave as
CC       penicillin-binding protein (PBP).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Preferential cleavage: (Ac)(2)-L-Lys-D-Ala-|-
CC       D-Ala. Also transpeptidation of peptidyl-alanyl moieties that are
CC       N-acyl substituents of D-alanine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Cell wall biogenesis; peptidoglycan biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S12 family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This protein is involved in the active transport of
CC       galactose and glucose. It plays a role in the chemotaxis towards
CC       the two sugars by interacting with the trg chemoreceptor.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium-binding site is structurally similar to that
CC       of EF-hand proteins, but is in two parts, with the last calcium
CC       ligand provided by Glu-228.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial solute-binding protein 2

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidation of primary alcohols including
CC       methanol.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A primary alcohol + 2 cytochrome c(L) = an
CC       aldehyde + 2 reduced cytochrome c(L) + 2 H(+).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 PQQ group per subunit. PQQ is inserted between
CC       disulfide Cys-142-Cys-143 and the indole ring of Trp-280 (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 calcium ion per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 heme group per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer of non identical chains (dehydrogenase,
CC       cytochrome, and two smaller unknown subunits).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial PQQ dehydrogenase family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 cytochrome c domain.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidation of primary alcohols including
CC       methanol (By similarity).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A primary alcohol + 2 cytochrome c(L) = an
CC       aldehyde + 2 reduced cytochrome c(L) + 2 H(+).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 PQQ group per subunit. PQQ is inserted between
CC       disulfide Cys-130-Cys-131 and the indole ring of Trp-270 (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 calcium ion per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer composed of 2 alpha and 2 beta subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein; Periplasmic side. Note=Periplasmic, but associated with
CC       inner membrane.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial PQQ dehydrogenase family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidation of primary alcohols including
CC       methanol (By similarity).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A primary alcohol + 2 cytochrome c(L) = an
CC       aldehyde + 2 reduced cytochrome c(L) + 2 H(+).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 PQQ group per subunit. PQQ is inserted between
CC       disulfide Cys-135-Cys-136 and the indole ring of Trp-275.

CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer composed of 2 alpha and 2 beta subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: MDH is the major protein in the cell during growth
CC       on methanol (in P.denitrificans MDH constitutes up to 15% of the
CC       total cell protein).

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidation of primary alcohols including
CC       methanol.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A primary alcohol + 2 cytochrome c(L) = an

CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the methanol dehydrogenase subunit 2

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.25 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=2085423; DOI=10.1107/S010876819000636X;
RA   Vellieux F.M.D., Kalk K.H., Hol W.G.J.;
RT   "Structure determination of quinoprotein methylamine dehydrogenase
RT   from Thiobacillus versutus.";
RL   Acta Crystallogr. B 46:806-823(1990).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Methylamine dehydrogenase carries out the oxidation of
CC       methylamine. Electrons are passed from methylamine dehydrogenase
CC       to amicyanin.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Methylamine + H(2)O + amicyanin = formaldehyde
CC       + ammonia + reduced amicyanin.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Contains 1 tryptophan tryptophylquinone per subunit.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: One-carbon metabolism; methylamine degradation;
CC       formaldehyde from methylamine: step 1/1.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of two light and two heavy chains.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- PTM: Predicted to be exported by the Tat system. The position of
CC       the signal peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven.
CC   -!- PTM: Tryptophan tryptophylquinone (TTQ) is formed by oxidation of
CC       the indole ring of a tryptophan to form tryptophylquinone followed
CC       by covalent cross-linking with another tryptophan residue.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the aromatic amine dehydrogenase light
CC       chain family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the reduction of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to
CC       dimethyl sulfide (DMS). DMSO reductase serves as the terminal
CC       reductase under anaerobic conditions, with DMSO being the terminal
CC       electron acceptor. Terminal reductase during anaerobic growth on
CC       various sulfoxides and N-oxide compounds. Allows E.coli to grow
CC       anaerobically on DMSO as respiratory oxidant.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dimethylsulfide + menaquinone + H(2)O =
CC       dimethylsulfoxide + menaquinol.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 4Fe-4S cluster (Potential).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 molybdenum-bis(molybdopterin guanine
CC       dinucleotide) (Mo-bis-MGD) cofactor per subunit.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by dithionite, sodium bisulfite and
CC       tungstate.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.043 mM for 2-chloropyridine N-oxide (at pH 5 and at 30
CC         degrees Celsius, PubMed=8969520);
CC         KM=0.045 mM for 3-amidopyridine N-oxide (at pH 5 and at 30
CC         degrees Celsius, PubMed=8969520);
CC         KM=0.06 mM for tertramethylene sulfoxide (at pH 5 and at 30
CC         degrees Celsius, PubMed=8969520);
CC         KM=0.09 mM for methionine sulfoxide (at pH 5 and at 30 degrees
CC         Celsius, PubMed=8969520);
CC         KM=0.246 mM for 4-phenylpyridine N-oxide (at pH 5 and at 30
CC         degrees Celsius, PubMed=8969520);
CC         KM=0.830 mM for dimethyldodecylamin N-oxide (at pH 5 and at 30
CC         degrees Celsius, PubMed=8969520);
CC         KM=0.18 mM for DMSO (at pH 6.8 and at 23 degrees Celsius,
CC         PubMed=3280546);
CC         KM=0.47 mM for L-methionine sulfoxide (at pH 6.8 and at 23
CC         degrees Celsius, PubMed=3280546);
CC         KM=0.5 mM for nicotinamide N-oxide (at pH 6.8 and at 23 degrees
CC         Celsius, PubMed=3280546);
CC         KM=0.6 mM for TMAO (at pH 6.8 and at 23 degrees Celsius,
CC         PubMed=3280546);
CC         KM=1.0 mM for 4-picoline N-oxide (at pH 6.8 and at 23 degrees
CC         Celsius, PubMed=3280546);
CC         KM=20.2 mM for TMAO (at pH 5 and at 30 degrees Celsius,
CC         PubMed=8969520);
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotrimeric enzyme composed of a catalytic heterodimer
CC       (DmsAB) and a membrane anchor protein (DmsC).
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P69853:dmsD; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-4411104, EBI-4406374;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Peripheral membrane protein;
CC       Cytoplasmic side.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven. Can also be
CC       exported by the Sec system.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The Tat signal sequence is essential for the
CC       expression of dmsA, the stability of the DmsAB dimer and membrane
CC       targeting. Despite the presence of a signal sequence, DmsA is not
CC       exported to the periplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the prokaryotic molybdopterin-containing
CC       oxidoreductase family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 4Fe-4S Mo/W bis-MGD-type domain.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA83843.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended;

RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;
RT   "Global topology analysis of the Escherichia coli inner membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required to facilitate the formation of correct
CC       disulfide bonds in some periplasmic proteins and for the assembly
CC       of the periplasmic c-type cytochromes. Acts by transferring
CC       electrons from cytoplasmic thioredoxin to the periplasm, thereby
CC       maintaining the active site of DsbC, DsbE and DsbG in a reduced
CC       state. This transfer involves a cascade of disulfide bond
CC       formation and reduction steps.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Protein dithiol + NAD(P)(+) = protein
CC       disulfide + NAD(P)H.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The consequences of replacement of the cysteines
CC       with alanines were found to depend on the conditions tested and on
CC       the reporter system used for the analysis, and then differ
CC       depending on the references.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the thioredoxin family. DsbD subfamily.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 thioredoxin domain.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA54781.1; Type=Erroneous initiation;
CC       Sequence=CAA85375.1; Type=Erroneous initiation;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Endohydrolysis of the di-N-acetylchitobiosyl unit in
CC       high-mannose glycopeptides and glycoproteins. Does not hydrolyze
CC       complex bi- or triantennary glycans. The presence of a core-bound
CC       fucose impedes endo F1 hydrolysis.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of the N,N'-diacetylchitobiosyl

CC       the -(Man(GlcNAc)(2))Asn-structure. One N-acetyl-D-glucosamine
CC       residue remains attached to the protein; the rest of the
CC       oligosaccharide is released intact.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Endohydrolysis of the di-N-acetylchitobiosyl unit in
CC       high-mannose glycopeptides and glycoproteins. Complex biantennary
CC       glycans are the preferred substrates. Tri- and tetraantennary
CC       glycans are not hydrolyzed, and high mannose glycans are very poor
CC       substrates.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of the N,N'-diacetylchitobiosyl
CC       unit in high-mannose glycopeptides and glycoproteins containing
CC       the -(Man(GlcNAc)(2))Asn-structure. One N-acetyl-D-glucosamine
CC       residue remains attached to the protein; the rest of the
CC       oligosaccharide is released intact.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- PTM: Carbohydrates at Ser-73, Ser-89 and Ser-143 consist of (2-
CC       OMe)Man1-4GlcNAcU1-4GlcU1-4Glc1-4(2-OMe)GlcU1-4[(2-OMe)Rham1-
CC       2]Man.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 18 family.

CC       inhibits chymotrypsin, trypsin, elastases, factor X, kallikrein as

CC       specificity.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 36-423 OF APOPROTEIN AND IN
RP   COMPLEXES WITH PROTOPORPHYRIN IX AND HEME, AND SUBUNIT.
RC   STRAIN=K12;
RA   Bamford V.A., Andrews S.C., Watson K.A.;
RT   "EfeB, the peroxidase component of the EfeUOB bacterial Fe(II)
RT   transport system, also shows novel removal of iron from heme.";
RL   Submitted (JAN-2011) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the recovery of exogenous heme iron.
CC       Extracts iron from heme while preserving the tetrapyrrol ring
CC       intact. Also displays peroxidase activity on guaiacol in vitro.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 heme B (iron-protoporphyrin IX) group non-
CC       covalently per subunit.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Part of a ferrous iron transporter composed of
CC       EfeU, EfeO and EfeB. However, this EfeUOB tripartite iron
CC       transporter is defective in E.coli strain K12 due to a frameshift
CC       mutation in EfeU.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Repressed by Fur in the presence of iron. Repressed at
CC       high pH by the two-component regulatory system CpxA/CpxR.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven. Can also be
CC       exported by the Sec system.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=43814; Method=Electrospray; Range=36-423;
CC       Source=PubMed:16551627;
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DyP-type peroxidase family. EfeB
CC       subfamily.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cleaves elastin, collagen, IgG, and several complement
CC       components. Involved in the pathogenesis of P.aeruginosa
CC       infections.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Hydrolysis of proteins including elastin,
CC       collagen types III and IV, fibronectin and immunoglobulin A,
CC       generally with bulky hydrophobic group at P1'. Insulin B chain
CC       cleavage pattern identical to that of thermolysin, but specificity
CC       differs in other respects.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 calcium ion per subunit.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The sequence shown is that of strain PAO.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase M4 family.

RN   [7]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.5 ANGSTROMS) OF 32-212.
RX   PubMed=11491291; DOI=10.1006/jmbi.2001.4659;
RA   van Pouderoyen G., Eggert T., Jaeger K.-E., Dijkstra B.W.;
RT   "The crystal structure of Bacillus subtilis lipase: a minimal
RT   alpha/beta hydrolase fold enzyme.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 309:215-226(2001).
RN   [8]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 32-212.
RX   PubMed=12077437; DOI=10.1107/S090744490200714X;
RA   Kawasaki K., Kondo H., Suzuki M., Ohgiya S., Tsuda S.;
RT   "Alternate conformations observed in catalytic serine of Bacillus
RT   subtilis lipase determined at 1.3 A resolution.";
RL   Acta Crystallogr. D 58:1168-1174(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Active toward p-nitrophenyl esters and triacylglycerides
CC       with a marked preference for esters with C8 acyl groups.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Triacylglycerol + H(2)O = diacylglycerol + a
CC       carboxylate.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Strongly inhibited when incubated with the
CC       serine reagent phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Activated by the
CC       addition of calcium to the reaction mixture. When calcium was
CC       incubated with the lipase but not added to the reaction mixture,
CC       its effect is lower but still observable. Magnesium, manganese and
CC       strontium are not able to replace calcium with full retention of
CC       activity.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 10. The activity decreases strongly above pH 10.5
CC         or below pH 6.5. The enzyme is remarkably stable at alkaline pH,
CC         showing maximum stability at pH 12 and retaining more than 65%
CC         of its activity after 24 hours at pH 13;
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 35 degrees Celsius. Stable for at least
CC         30 minutes at 40 degrees Celsius. Virtually no activity remains
CC         after 30 minutes at 55 degrees Celsius;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Maximally expressed in late exponential growth phase.
CC       Expression decreases rapidly in the stationary phase. Expressed in
CC       both rich and minimal media.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the AB hydrolase superfamily.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in translocation of long-chain fatty acids
CC       across the outer membrane. It is a receptor for the bacteriophage
CC       T2. FadL may form a specific channel.

CC       homodimer.

CC       protein.

CC       the control of the FadR repressor.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Fimbriae (also called pili), polar filaments radiating
CC       from the surface of the bacterium to a length of 0.5-1.5
CC       micrometers and numbering 100-300 per cell, enable bacteria to
CC       colonize the epithelium of specific host organs.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: K88 fimbria, 0.1-1 micrometer in length and 7 nanometers
CC       in diameter, is composed of about 100 identical subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Fimbrium. Note=Predominantly located at the
CC       tip of the fimbriae.

RX   PubMed=1400188;
RA   Bakker D., Willemsen P.T.J., Willems R.H., Huisman T.T., Mooi F.R.,
RA   Oudega B., Stegehuis F., de Graaf F.K.;
RT   "Identification of minor fimbrial subunits involved in biosynthesis of
RT   K88 fimbriae.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 174:6350-6358(1992).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: K88 major fimbrial subunit. Fimbriae (also called pili),
CC       are polar filaments radiating from the surface of the bacterium to
CC       a length of 0.5-1.5 micrometers and numbering 100-300 per cell.
CC       They enable bacteria to colonize the epithelium of specific host
CC       organs.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: K88 fimbria, 0.1-1 micrometer in length and 7 nanometers
CC       in diameter, is composed of about 100 identical subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Fimbrium.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The protein exists in several antigenic variants.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the fimbrial K88 protein family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the ABC transporter complex FbpABC
CC       (TC 3.A.1.10.1) involved in Fe(3+) ions import. This protein
CC       specifically binds Fe(3+) and is involved in its transmembrane
CC       transport (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (FbpC), two transmembrane proteins (FbpB) and a solute-binding
CC       protein (FbpA) (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm (Probable).
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By iron deprivation.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial solute-binding protein 1
CC       family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This protein may be a central component in the iron-
CC       acquisition system.

CC   -!- INDUCTION: By iron deprivation.

CC       protein as a Fe(3+) ion at an approximate molar ratio of 1:1.

CC       family.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA] OF 731-774.
RC   STRAIN=K12;
RX   PubMed=2651410;
RA   Staudenmaier H., van Hove B., Yaraghi Z., Braun V.;
RT   "Nucleotide sequences of the fecBCDE genes and locations of the
RT   proteins suggest a periplasmic-binding-protein-dependent transport
RT   mechanism for iron(III) dicitrate in Escherichia coli.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 171:2626-2633(1989).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: FecA is the outer membrane receptor protein in the
CC       Fe(3+) dicitrate transport system.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: For induction, the TonB and the ExbB proteins have to
CC       be active. Regulation by the iron level mediated by the Fur
CC       protein and induction by citrate plus iron suggest that the Fe(3+)
CC       dicitrate complex must enter the periplasm where it binds to a
CC       transmembrane protein, which regulates transcription of the fec
CC       genes directly or via a further inductor.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TonB-dependent receptor family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This protein is involved in the initial step of iron
CC       uptake by binding ferrienterobactin (Fe-ENT), an iron chelatin
CC       siderophore that allows E.coli to extract iron from the
CC       environment. FepA also acts as a receptor for colicins B and D.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P02929:tonB; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6400027, EBI-6399993;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TonB-dependent receptor family.

RN   [11]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.95 ANGSTROMS) OF 34-747.
RX   PubMed=10850805;
RA   Ferguson A.D., Braun V., Fiedler H.-P., Coulton J.W., Diederichs K.,
RA   Welte W.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the antibiotic albomycin in complex with the
RT   outer membrane transporter FhuA.";
RL   Protein Sci. 9:956-963(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This receptor binds the ferrichrome-iron ligand. It
CC       interacts with the TonB protein, which is responsible for energy
CC       coupling of the ferrichrome-promoted iron transport system. Acts
CC       as a receptor for bacteriophage T5 as well as T1, phi80 and
CC       colicin M. Binding of T5 triggers the opening of a high
CC       conductance ion channel. Can also transport the antibiotic
CC       albomycin.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TonB-dependent receptor family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RL   J. Biol. Chem. 277:13966-13972(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the ABC transporter complex FhuCDB involved in
CC       iron(3+)-hydroxamate import. Binds the iron(3+)-hydroxamate
CC       complex and transfers it to the membrane-bound permease. Required
CC       for the transport of all iron(3+)-hydroxamate siderophores such as
CC       ferrichrome, gallichrome, desferrioxamine, coprogen, aerobactin,
CC       shizokinen, rhodotorulic acid and the antibiotic albomycin.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of an ATP-binding protein (FhuC),
CC       two transmembrane proteins (FhuB) and a solute-binding protein
CC       (FhuD).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven. Can also be
CC       exported by the Sec system.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial solute-binding protein 8
CC       family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 Fe/B12 periplasmic-binding domain.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in regulation of length and mediation of
CC       adhesion of type 1 fimbriae (but not necessary for the production
CC       of fimbriae). Adhesin responsible for the binding to D-mannose. It
CC       is laterally positioned at intervals in the structure of the type
CC       1 fimbriae. In order to integrate FimH in the fimbriae FimF and
CC       FimG are needed.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P31697:fimC; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-1028015, EBI-1028005;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Fimbrium.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the fimbrial protein family.

RT   Bordetella parapertussis and Bordetella bronchiseptica.";
RL   Nat. Genet. 35:32-40(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Bordetella pertussis is the causative agent of whooping
CC       cough. An essential step in the disease process is the attachment
CC       of the bacteria to the ciliated epithelium of the respiratory
CC       tract, enabling the organism to resist normal host-clearance
CC       mechanisms. It is unclear which bacterial cell surface component
CC       are responsible for adherence but the fimbriae of B.pertussis are
CC       prime candidates for being involved in this process.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Fimbrium. Note=Pili structure on the cell
CC       surface.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the fimbrial protein family.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAE41417.1; Type=Erroneous initiation;

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA].

RX   PubMed=1360140; DOI=10.1111/j.1365-2958.1992.tb01449.x;

RN   [2]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 25-70.
RC   STRAIN=Ah26;
RX   PubMed=1974915; DOI=10.1084/jem.172.3.795;
RA   Ho A.S.Y., Mietzner T.A., Smith A.J., Schoolnik G.K.;
RT   "The pili of Aeromonas hydrophila: identification of an
RT   environmentally regulated 'mini pilin'.";
RL   J. Exp. Med. 172:795-806(1990).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Fimbriae (also called pili) are polar filaments
CC       radiating from the surface of the bacterium to a length of 0.5-1.5
CC       micrometers and numbering 100-300 per cell. They enable bacteria
CC       to colonize the epithelium of specific host organs. Flexible pili
CC       possess hemagglutinating function.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopolymer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Fimbrium.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: A.hydrophila possesses two distinctive pilus types:
CC       "straight" pili appears as brittle, rod-like filaments, whereas
CC       "flexible" pili are supple and curvilinear.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RL   Biochemistry 46:7226-7232(2007).
RN   [14]
RP   CHARACTERIZATION OF FIBRINOGEN AND ELASTIN-BINDING DOMAINS, AND
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF GLY-222; ARG-224; ASN-304; PHE-306; THR-354; PHE-355;
RP   ASN-356; LYS-357; ALA-415; THR-417; 484-TYR--ASN-511; GLY-497;
RP   LEU-498; 499-VAL--ASN-511 AND 510-LYS-ASN-511.
RX   PubMed=17302800; DOI=10.1111/j.1365-2958.2006.05552.x;
RA   Keane F.M., Loughman A., Valtulina V., Brennan M., Speziale P.,
RA   Foster T.J.;
RT   "Fibrinogen and elastin bind to the same region within the A domain of
RT   fibronectin binding protein A, an MSCRAMM of Staphylococcus aureus.";
RL   Mol. Microbiol. 63:711-723(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Possesses multiple, substituting fibronectin (Fn)
CC       binding regions, each capable of conferring adherence to both
CC       soluble and immobilized forms of Fn. This confers to S.aureus the
CC       ability to invade endothelial cells both in vivo and in vitro,
CC       without requiring additional factors, although in a slow and
CC       inefficient way through actin rearrangements in host cells. This
CC       invasion process is mediated by integrin alpha-5/beta-1. Promotes
CC       bacterial attachment to both soluble and immobilized forms of
CC       fibrinogen (Fg) by means of a unique binding site localized within
CC       the 17 C-terminal residues of the gamma-chain of human Fg. Both
CC       plasma proteins (Fn and Fg) function as a bridge between bacterium
CC       and host cell. Promotes attachment to immobilized elastin peptides
CC       in a dose-dependent and saturable manner. Promotes attachment to
CC       both full-length and segments of immobilized human tropoelastin at
CC       multiple sites in a dose and pH-dependent manner. Promotes
CC       adherence to and aggregation of activated platelets independently
CC       of other S.aureus surface molecules. Is a critical mediator
CC       implicated in the induction of experimental endocarditis in rats
CC       with catheter-induced aortic vegetations, promoting both
CC       colonization and persistence of the bacterium into the host.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P02751:FN1 (xeno); NbExp=18; IntAct=EBI-8398157, EBI-1220319;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, cell wall; Peptidoglycan-anchor
CC       (Potential).
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expressed predominantly on cells from early exponential
CC       phase of growth. Up-regulated by sigma-B factor during early
CC       growth stages but not in later stages, although this positive
CC       effect on transcription is most probably indirect. Up-regulated by
CC       SarA. Down-regulated by Agr.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Fg-binding activity is not regulated by the
CC       divalent cations Ca(2+), Mn(2+) or Mg(2+).
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Deletion of the Fg-binding domain of FnbA abrogates
CC       the ability to promote cardiac valve infection and persistence in
CC       vivo.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The mutagenesis studies described in
CC       PubMed:17302800 were done with region A alone and not with the
CC       entire protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Mutants lacking C-terminal residues from the ligand
CC       binding A region bind to Fg with a reduced affinity or are unable
CC       to bind to both Fg and elastin, depending on the extension of the
CC       deletion present in this region. Individual constructs of regions
CC       spanning amino acids from 194-336 or 337-511 were unable to bind
CC       fibrinogen or elastin.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=ABD31806.1; Type=Erroneous initiation;
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RC   STRAIN=K12;
RX   PubMed=19135451; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2008.12.043;
RA   Tarry M., Arends S.J., Roversi P., Piette E., Sargent F., Berks B.C.,
RA   Weiss D.S., Lea S.M.;
RT   "The Escherichia coli cell division protein and model Tat substrate
RT   SufI (FtsP) localizes to the septal ring and has a multicopper
RT   oxidase-like structure.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 386:504-519(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cell division protein that is required for growth during
CC       stress conditions. May be involved in protecting or stabilizing
CC       the divisomal assembly under conditions of stress.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm. Note=Localizes to the division
CC       septum. Localization requires FtsZ, FtsQ, FtsL and FtsN.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven. Can also be
CC       exported by the Sec system.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells lacking this gene are sensitive to
CC       oxidative stress and DNA damage at high temperature. They also
CC       exhibit filamentation.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Is used as a model substrate in studies of the
CC       twin-arginine translocation (Tat) protein transport system.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FtsP family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 plastocyanin-like domain.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 30-189 AND 199-720 OF
RP   WILD-TYPE AND 30-720 OF MUTANT ALA-199, SUBUNIT, MUTAGENESIS OF
RP   SER-199, AND AUTOCATALYTIC PROCESSING MECHANISM.
RX   PubMed=12680762; DOI=10.1021/bi027181x;
RA   Kim J.K., Yang I.S., Rhee S., Dauter Z., Lee Y.S., Park S.S.,
RA   Kim K.H.;
RT   "Crystal structures of glutaryl 7-aminocephalosporanic acid acylase:
RT   insight into autoproteolytic activation.";
RL   Biochemistry 42:4084-4093(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the deacylation of 7 beta-(4-
CC       carboxybutanamido)cephalosporanic acid (glutaryl-7-
CC       aminocephalosporanic acid or GL-7-ACA) to 7-aminocephalosporanic
CC       acid (7-ACA).
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (7R)-7-(4-carboxybutanamido)cephalosporanate +
CC       H(2)O = (7R)-7-aminocephalosporanate + glutarate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of two alpha and two beta subunits
CC       processed from the same precursor.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By glutaric acid.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S45 family.

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A (5-L-glutamyl)-peptide + an amino acid = a

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A (5-L-glutamyl)-peptide + an amino acid = a
CC       peptide + a 5-L-glutamyl amino acid.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Glutathione + H(2)O = L-cysteinylglycine + L-
CC       glutamate.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Sulfur metabolism; glutathione metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: This enzyme consists of two polypeptide chains, which are
CC       synthesized in precursor form from a single polypeptide.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm (By similarity).
CC   -!- PTM: Cleaved by autocatalysis into a large and a small subunit.

RP   MAGNESIUM IONS, AND SUBUNIT.

RT   "The crystal structure of glycerophosphoryl diester phosphodiesterase
RT   from E. coli.";
RL   Submitted (MAY-2007) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glycerophosphoryl diester phosphodiesterase hydrolyzes
CC       deacylated phospholipids to G3P and the corresponding alcohols.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A glycerophosphodiester + H(2)O = an alcohol +
CC       sn-glycerol 3-phosphate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 calcium ion per subunit.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.28 mM for glycerophosphocholine;
CC         KM=0.24 mM for glycerophosphoethanolamine;
CC         KM=0.35 mM for glycerophosphoglycerol;
CC         KM=0.59 mM for glycerophosphoserine;
CC         KM=1.0 mM for glycerophosphoinositol;
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7.8;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 isozymes of glycerophosphoryl diester
CC       phosphodiesterase in E.coli: a periplasmic isozyme (GlpQ) and a
CC       cytosolic isozyme (UgpQ).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycerophosphoryl diester
CC       phosphodiesterase family.
