RP   FUNCTION IN SLAPS FORMATION.
RC   STRAIN=10403S / Serovar 1/2a;
RX   PubMed=18202661; DOI=10.1038/nature06479;
RA   Birmingham C.L., Canadien V., Kaniuk N.A., Steinberg B.E.,
RA   Higgins D.E., Brumell J.H.;
RT   "Listeriolysin O allows Listeria monocytogenes replication in

RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION.
RC   STRAIN=EGD / Serovar 1/2a;
RX   PubMed=20414307; DOI=10.1038/nature08963;
RA   Ribet D., Hamon M., Gouin E., Nahori M.A., Impens F., Neyret-Kahn H.,
RA   Gevaert K., Vandekerckhove J., Dejean A., Cossart P.;
RT   "Listeria monocytogenes impairs SUMOylation for efficient infection.";
RL   Nature 464:1192-1195(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Sulfhydryl-activated pore-forming toxin, which is a
CC       major virulence factor required for the escape of bacteria from
CC       phagosomal vacuoles and entry into the host cytosol. After binding
CC       to target membranes, the protein undergoes a major conformation
CC       change, leading to its insertion in the host membrane and
CC       formation of an oligomeric pore complex. Listeriolysin O activates
CC       mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase activity in host cells,
CC       most likely as a result of the permeabilization of the host cell
CC       membrane. Also induces a proteasome-independent degradation of
CC       UBE2I (the SUMO-conjugating enzyme UBC9) and a proteasome-
CC       dependent degradation of some sumoylated proteins. Finally, is
CC       necessary and sufficient for spacious Listeria-containing
CC       phagosomes (SLAPs) formation, suggesting a role for listeriolysin
CC       O in promoting L.monocytogenes replication in vacuoles, leading to
CC       persistent infection.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activity of listeriolysin O is regulated on
CC       multiple levels. It should be high in the phagosome, thereby
CC       allowing escape of the bacteria from the phagosomal compartment.
CC       Then, once inside the host cytosol, the activity must be
CC       controlled to prevent lysis of the host plasma membrane and loss
CC       of the intracellular environment. Multiple regulatory mechanisms
CC       include translational repression, which is required to minimize
CC       levels of listeriolysin O in the host cytosol. In addition,
CC       cytolytic activity is pH-dependent. Activity is high in the acidic
CC       environment of the phagosome and is turned off in the neutral pH
CC       of the cytosol. Listeriolysin O is also ubiquitinated and rapidly
CC       degraded by host proteasome in cytosol. The lytic activity is
CC       activated by reducing agents and suppressed by oxidation. Also
CC       inhibited by very low amounts of cholesterol.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 5.5. Cytolytic activity is undetectable at pH 7.0;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homooligomeric pore complex; when inserted in the host
CC       membrane.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6407357, EBI-6407357;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Host membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein. Host cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Note=Secreted as soluble protein that then inserts into the host
CC       membrane and forms pores formed by transmembrane beta-strands (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminal region is not required for secretion and
CC       hemolytic activity, but is involved in phagosomal escape of
CC       bacteria in infected cells and is critical for bacterial
CC       virulence. This region contains a PEST-like sequence, which does
CC       not mediate proteasomal degradation, but controls listeriolysin O
CC       production in the cytosol.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Phosphorylation does not appear to be
CC       required for ubiquitination or degradation.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the thiol-activated cytolysin family.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA69528.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened;
CC       Sequence=AAA69531.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened;

FT                                and no stimulation of MAP kinase
FT                                activity. Does not affect membrane-

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA].

RA   Haas A., Dumbsky M., Kreft J.;

RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=11583846; DOI=10.1111/j.1574-6968.2001.tb10839.x;
RA   Ito Y., Kawamura I., Kohda C., Baba H., Kimoto T., Watanabe I.,
RA   Nomura T., Mitsuyama M.;
RT   "Difference in cholesterol-binding and cytolytic activities between
RT   listeriolysin O and seeligeriolysin O: a possible role of alanine
RT   residue in tryptophan-rich undecapeptide.";
RL   FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 203:185-189(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Sulfhydryl-activated toxin that causes cytolysis by
CC       forming pores in cholesterol containing host membranes. After
CC       binding to target membranes, the protein undergoes a major
CC       conformation change, leading to its insertion in the host membrane
CC       and formation of an oligomeric pore complex. Cholesterol may be
CC       required for binding to host membranes, membrane insertion and
CC       pore formation. Can be reversibly inactivated by oxidation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homooligomeric pore complex; when inserted in the host
CC       membrane (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted (By similarity). Host cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein (By similarity).
CC       Note=Secreted as soluble protein that then inserts into the host
CC       membrane and forms pores formed by transmembrane beta-strands (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the thiol-activated cytolysin family.

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 33-60.
RA   Alouf J.E., Geoffroy C., Gilles A.M., Falmagne P.;
RL   (In) Rappuoli R., Alouf J.E., Falmagne P. (eds.);
RL   Bacterial protein toxins, pp.49-50, Gustav Fisher Verlag, Stuttgart
RL   (1990).
RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=6411708;
RA   Geoffroy C., Alouf J.E.;
RT   "Selective purification by thiol-disulfide interchange chromatography
RT   of alveolysin, a sulfhydryl-activated toxin of Bacillus alvei. Toxin
RT   properties and interaction with cholesterol and liposomes.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 258:9968-9972(1983).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Sulfhydryl-activated toxin that causes cytolysis by
CC       forming pores in cholesterol containing host membranes. After
CC       binding to target membranes, the protein undergoes a major
CC       conformation change, leading to its insertion in the host membrane
CC       and formation of an oligomeric pore complex. Cholesterol may be
CC       required for binding to host cell membranes, membrane insertion
CC       and pore formation. Can be reversibly inactivated by oxidation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homooligomeric pore complex; when inserted in the host
CC       membrane.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Host cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Note=Secreted as soluble protein that then
CC       inserts into the host cell membrane and forms pores formed by
CC       transmembrane beta-strands (By similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the thiol-activated cytolysin family.

CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be a sulfotransferase involved in the transport of
CC       sulfate. Displays very low rhodanese activity.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Thiosulfate + cyanide = sulfite + thiocyanate.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By sulfur deprivation.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Contains two rhodanese domains with different primary
CC       structures but with near identical secondary structure
CC       conformations suggesting a common evolutionary origin. Only the C-
CC       terminal rhodanese domain contains the catalytic cysteine residue
CC       (By similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 rhodanese domains.

RN   [11]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.1 ANGSTROMS) OF 23-450.
RX   PubMed=10879525; DOI=10.1038/35016007;
RA   Koronakis V., Sharff A., Koronakis E., Luisi B., Hughes C.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the bacterial membrane protein TolC central to
RT   multidrug efflux and protein export.";
RL   Nature 405:914-919(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for proper expression of outer membrane
CC       proteins such as OmpF, NmpC, protein 2, hemolysin, colicin V, or
CC       colicin E1. May be specialized for signal sequence independent,
CC       extracellular secretion in Gram-negative bacteria.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: AcrA-AcrB-AcrZ-TolC is a drug efflux protein complex
CC       with broad substrate specificity that uses the proton motive force
CC       to export substrates.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer that assembles to form a continuous, solvent-
CC       accessible conduit: a 'channel-tunnel' over 140 Angstroms long
CC       that spans both the outer membrane and periplasmic space. The
CC       periplasmic or proximal end of the tunnel is sealed by sets of
CC       coiled helices. Can be part of the AcrA-AcrB-AcrZ-TolC efflux
CC       pump; AcrA may be required to stably link this protein with AcrB.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cannot grow on efflux substrates novobiocin
CC       or fusidic acid.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the outer membrane factor (OMF) (TC 1.B.17)
CC       family.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA69203.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened;
CC       Sequence=CAA24751.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened;
CC       Sequence=CAA37982.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened;

RL   J. Biol. Chem. 282:8309-8316(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Reduces trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO) into
CC       trimethylamine; an anaerobic reaction coupled to energy-yielding
CC       reactions.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Trimethylamine + 2 (ferricytochrome c)-subunit
CC       + H(2)O = trimethylamine N-oxide + 2 (ferrocytochrome c)-subunit +
CC       2 H(+).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 molybdenum-bis(molybdopterin guanine
CC       dinucleotide) (Mo-bis-MGD) cofactor per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the N-terminal domain of TorC.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P0A9M0:lon; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-557008, EBI-547203;
CC       P36662:torD; NbExp=24; IntAct=EBI-557008, EBI-6406226;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the prokaryotic molybdopterin-containing
CC       oxidoreductase family.

RC   STRAIN=10536;
RX   PubMed=8075982; DOI=10.1016/S0969-2126(00)00007-1;

RN   [21]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.7 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH ATP.
RX   PubMed=8637000; DOI=10.1006/jmbi.1996.0277;
RA   Hazes B., Boodhoo A., Cockle S.A., Read R.J.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the pertussis toxin-ATP complex: a molecular
RT   sensor.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 258:661-671(1996).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: S1 is an NAD-dependent ADP-ribosyltransferase, which
CC       plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of B.pertussis causing
CC       disruption of normal host cellular regulation. It catalyzes the
CC       ADP-ribosylation of a cysteine in the alpha subunit of host
CC       heterotrimeric G proteins. In the absence of G proteins it also
CC       catalyzes the cleavage of NAD(+) into ADP-ribose and nicotinamide.
CC       It irreversibly uncouples the G-alpha GTP-binding proteins from
CC       their membrane receptors.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pertussis toxin contains five different chains, S1-S5.
CC       They are organized into 2 functional subunits: A, composed of S1
CC       (which is toxic) and B, containing S2, S3, S5, and two copies of
CC       S4 (B binds to the membrane receptors). Dimers of S2-S4 and S3-S4
CC       are held together by S5.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Note=The individual chains are
CC       secreted by a sec-dependent mechanism into the periplasm. Then, S1
CC       associates with the outer membrane before it joins with the B
CC       subunit to form the secretion-competent holotoxin. The type IV
CC       secretion system ptl mediates secretion of assembled toxin through
CC       the outer membrane.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Activated by the two-component regulatory system
CC       BvgS/BvgA.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The region which spans amino-acids 42-49 is required for
CC       enzymatic activity and contributes to the formation of a
CC       potentially important antigenic determinant.
CC   -!- PHARMACEUTICAL: Currently used in vaccines available under the
CC       names Daptacel (Sanofi Pasteur), Infanrix (GlaxoSmithKline),
CC       Pediarix (GlaxoSmithKline), TriHIBit (Sanofi Pasteur) and Tripedia
CC       (Sanofi Pasteur).
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Thiol:disulfide oxidoreductases DsbA and DsbB are
CC       required for periplasmic toxin assembly, whereas DbsC is important
CC       for extracellular toxin secretion.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Experiments with temporal expression of PTX
CC       indicate that holotoxin secretion is at a rate of 3
CC       molecules/min/cell. Also, more of toxin chains S1, S2 and S3 are
CC       produced than secreted; one half of each chain is incorporated
CC       into holotoxin.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial exotoxin subunit A family.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RT   "Crystal structure of the pertussis toxin-ATP complex: a molecular
RT   sensor.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 258:661-671(1996).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: PTX oligomer B binds to receptors on the eukaryotic cell
CC       surface and facilitates the translocation of the toxic subunit
CC       across the cell membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pertussis toxin contains five different chains, S1-S5.
CC       They are organized into 2 functional subunits: A, composed of S1
CC       (which is toxic) and B, containing S2, S3, S5, and two copies of
CC       S4 (B binds to the membrane receptors). Dimers of S2-S4 and S3-S4
CC       are held together by S5.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Host cell membrane (Potential).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the pertussis toxin S2/S3 subunits family.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: PTX oligomer B binds to receptors on the eukaryotic cell
CC       surface and facilitates the translocation of the toxic subunit
CC       across the cell membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pertussis toxin contains five different chains, S1-S5.
CC       They are organized into 2 functional subunits: A, composed of S1
CC       (which is toxic) and B, containing S2, S3, S5, and two copies of
CC       S4 (B binds to the membrane receptors). Dimers of S2-S4 and S3-S4
CC       are held together by S5.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted. Host cell membrane (Potential).

CC       Sequence=AAA22984.1; Type=Erroneous initiation;

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.35 ANGSTROMS) OF 425-630 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   YEAST EEF2 AND NAD, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-481; GLU-571; ARG-576 AND
RP   GLU-578.
RX   PubMed=18583986; DOI=10.1038/embor.2008.90;
RA   Jorgensen R., Wang Y., Visschedyk D., Merrill A.R.;
RT   "The nature and character of the transition state for the ADP-
RT   ribosyltransferase reaction.";
RL   EMBO Rep. 9:802-809(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: An NAD-dependent ADP-ribosyltransferase (ADPRT).
CC       Catalyzes the transfer of the ADP ribosyl moiety of oxidized NAD
CC       (NAD(+)) onto eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2) thus
CC       arresting protein synthesis. Has an LD(50) of 65 ng/ml against the
CC       human lung epithelial cell line C38.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: NAD(+) + diphthamide-[translation elongation
CC       factor 2] = nicotinamide + N-(ADP-D-ribosyl)diphthamide-
CC       [translation elongation factor 2].
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by 1,8-naphthalimide (NAP) as well as
CC       a number of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibitors and other
CC       compounds.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=121 uM for NAD;
CC         Note=For ADP-ribosyltransferase activity of the catalytic
CC         fragment 399-605;
CC   -!- PTM: The 8 cysteines participate in intrachain disulfide bonds.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RC   STRAIN=K12;
RX   PubMed=19123216; DOI=10.1002/chem.200801578;
RA   Cardona F., Parmeggiani C., Faggi E., Bonaccini C., Gratteri P.,
RA   Sim L., Gloster T.M., Roberts S., Davies G.J., Rose D.R., Goti A.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Provides the cells with the ability to utilize trehalose
CC       at high osmolarity by splitting it into glucose molecules that can
CC       subsequently be taken up by the phosphotransferase-mediated uptake
CC       system.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Alpha,alpha-trehalose + H(2)O = beta-D-glucose
CC       + alpha-D-glucose.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By growth at high osmolarity, is regulated by cAMP.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 37 family.

CC       monophosphate and glucose-1-phosphate, which can then be used by
CC       the cell.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-sugar + H(2)O = UMP + alpha-D-aldose 1-
CC       phosphate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A 5'-ribonucleotide + H(2)O = a ribonucleoside
CC       + phosphate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 zinc ions per subunit.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The activity of this protein is inhibited by an
CC       intracellular protein inhibitor.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm. Note=Exported from the cell,
CC       except a small proportion that is internally localized.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 5'-nucleotidase family.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RT   "Escherichia coli proteome analysis using the gene-protein database.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the high-affinity D-xylose membrane
CC       transport system. Binds with high affinity to xylose.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Periplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: E.coli has two D-xylose transport systems that
CC       accumulate sugar against a concentration gradient: the XylE system
CC       which utilizes the electrochemical gradient of protons and that is
CC       insensitive to cold osmotic shock and the XylF system that uses a
CC       high-energy phosphate compound and is sensitive to cold osmotic
CC       shock.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial solute-binding protein 2
CC       family.

OX   NCBI_TaxID=28896;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA], AND PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 34-41.
RC   STRAIN=ATCC 49915 / DSM 7060 / B6A-RI;
RX   PubMed=8215382;
RA   Lee Y.-E., Lowe S.E., Zeikus J.G.;
RT   "Gene cloning, sequencing, and biochemical characterization of
RT   endoxylanase from Thermoanaerobacterium saccharolyticum B6A-RI.";
RL   Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 59:3134-3137(1993).
RN   [2]
RP   ACTIVE SITE, AND MUTAGENESIS.
RX   PubMed=8376336;
RA   Lee Y.-E., Lowe S.E., Henrissat B., Zeikus J.G.;
RT   "Characterization of the active site and thermostability regions of
RT   endoxylanase from Thermoanaerobacterium saccharolyticum B6A-RI.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 175:5890-5898(1993).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Endo-acting enzyme that randomly cleaves the internal
CC       xylosidic linkages of the xylan backbone, yielding
CC       xylooligosaccharides of various lengths which are further
CC       hydrolyzed to xylose molecules by beta-xylosidase (EC 3.2.1.37).
CC       Requires at least three xylose residues for catalytic activity.
CC       Does not have activity against xylobiose.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of (1->4)-beta-D-xylosidic
CC       linkages in xylans.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 5.5;
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 70 degrees Celsius;
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycan degradation; xylan degradation.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By xylan and xylose.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 10 (cellulase F)
CC       family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 CBM-cenC (cenC-type cellulose-binding)
CC       domains.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 SLH (S-layer homology) domains.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC       major component of plant cell-walls.

DE            Short=Xylanase C;
DE            EC=3.2.1.8;
DE   AltName: Full=1,4-beta-D-xylan xylanohydrolase C;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=xlnC;
OS   Streptomyces lividans.
OC   Bacteria; Actinobacteria; Actinobacteridae; Actinomycetales;
OC   Streptomycineae; Streptomycetaceae; Streptomyces.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=1916;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA], AND PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 50-80.
RC   STRAIN=66 / 1326;
RX   PubMed=1743521; DOI=10.1016/0378-1119(91)90299-Q;
RA   Shareck F., Roy C., Yaguchi M., Morosoli R., Kluepfel D.;
RT   "Sequences of three genes specifying xylanases in Streptomyces
RT   lividans.";
RL   Gene 107:75-82(1991).
RN   [2]
RP   EXPORT VIA THE TAT-SYSTEM, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-23 AND ARG-24.
RX   PubMed=15158723; DOI=10.1016/j.bbapap.2004.02.008;
RA   Faury D., Saidane S., Li H., Morosoli R.;
RT   "Secretion of active xylanase C from Streptomyces lividans is
RT   exclusively mediated by the Tat protein export system.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1699:155-162(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Contributes to hydrolyze hemicellulose, the major
CC       component of plant cell-walls.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of (1->4)-beta-D-xylosidic
CC       linkages in xylans.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycan degradation; xylan degradation.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- PTM: Exported by the Tat system. The position of the signal
CC       peptide cleavage has been experimentally proven.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Replacement of the wild-type signal peptide with a
CC       Sec-dependent signal peptide resulted in a mature product that was
CC       translocated but that lacked enzymatic activity. The lack of
CC       activity was probably due to an incorrect folding. No xylanase
CC       activity and no XlnC protein were detected in the supernatant of a
CC       tatC mutant.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 11 (cellulase G)
CC       family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   CRYSTALLIZATION.
RC   STRAIN=6471/76 / Serotype O:3; PLASMID=pYV6471/76;
RX   PubMed=12037311; DOI=10.1107/S0907444902005231;
RA   Nummelin H., El Tahir Y., Ollikka P., Skurnik M., Goldman A.;
RT   "Expression, purification and crystallization of a collagen-binding
RT   fragment of Yersinia adhesin YadA.";
RL   Acta Crystallogr. D 58:1042-1044(2002).
RN   [9]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.55 ANGSTROMS) OF 26-241.
RC   STRAIN=6471/76 / Serotype O:3;
RX   PubMed=14765110; DOI=10.1038/sj.emboj.7600100;
RA   Nummelin H., Merckel M.C., Leo J.C., Lankinen H., Skurnik M.,
RA   Goldman A.;
RT   "The Yersinia adhesin YadA collagen-binding domain structure is a
RT   novel left-handed parallel beta-roll.";
RL   EMBO J. 23:701-711(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Collagen-binding outer membrane protein forming a
CC       fibrillar matrix on the bacterial cell surface. Promotes initial
CC       attachment and invasion of eukaryotic cells. Also protects the
CC       bacteria by being responsible for agglutination, serum resistance,
CC       complement inactivation and phagocytosis resistance.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced at 37 degrees Celsius by the temperature-
CC       dependent transcriptional activator LcrF (VirF).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Presents a lollipop-shaped form which consists of three
CC       domains: a C-terminal membrane-anchor domain, a coiled-coil stalk
CC       domain and an oval N-terminal head domain. The N-terminal half of
CC       the sequence reveals the presence of repeated motifs with the
CC       consensus sequence NSVAIGXXS. They form the turns and hydrophobic
CC       core of the nine-coiled left-handed parallel beta-roll and trimer
CC       structure essential for the collagen-binding activity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the autotransporter-2 (TC 1.B.40) /
CC       oligomeric coiled-coil adhesin (Oca) family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
